brief_description: Integrate two high-throughput technologies namely, microengraving-based screening of primary B cells and next-generation sequencing to examine the relationship between the diversity and quality of humoral responses raised and the severity of disease.
brief_title: Humoral responses to West Nile virus
condition_studied: Antibody responses to infection with West Nile virus
description: Integrate two high-throughput technologies namely, microengraving-based screening of primary B cells and next-generation sequencing to examine the relationship between the diversity and quality of humoral responses raised and the severity of disease.
endpoints: Next-generation sequencing for pools of B cells isolated from subject.
hypothesis: We hypothesize that differential production of antibody responses, limited clonotypic diversity, isotype biasing, or lower quality (affinity) antibodies may be key components of susceptibility to severe disease.
objectives: Determine how humoral responses relate to severity of disease to provide insight to predicting outcomes.
official_title: High-throughput immunophenotypic analyses of humoral responses to West Nile virus

program.contract_name: Defining signatures for immune responsiveness by functional systems immunology HIPC1
